content:
In the case of Boz One Pty Ltd v McLellan [2015] VSCA 68; 105 ACSR 325, paragraph 206 reads:

The ambit of s 127(4) of the Act was considered by Young CJ in Eq in Prime Constructions Pty Ltd v Westbridge Investments Pty Ltd.[128] He observed that it was not particularly clear what s 127(4) covered, but that it seemed to cover: the common law method of executing a deed; the method of execution that was prescribed by the company's constitution; or a situation where, by virtue of some estoppel, the deed was binding on the company.[129] Einstein J in Guang Dong Zhi Gao Australia Pty Ltd v Fortuna Network Pty Ltd[130] cited Young CJ in Eq’s reasons with approval and similarly stated that it was not particularly clear what s 127(4) covered.[131] In Sunbay Projects Pty Ltd v PR Wieland Holdings Pty Ltd,[132] Ann Lyons J stated, in the context of a discussion of s 127(4), that ‘there is no requirement that when a document is signed by a corporate entity, there is a particular formality which is required’.[133]

What does this mean?
